addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable my very singular good Lord, the L. Burghley Lord highe Treasuro
r
of England

16 Ja
n
1590
M
r
Bodeleie to my L.
The purpose of the
States
to be suito
r
s to hir
Ma
tie
for
e [engreatinge] of
e English Horseband
./

page.lettertext:
fol.48r
May it please yo
r
good L. wheras petition hath
bin made to the General States, for
e increa-
sing of
e forces of these contreis, w
t
an extra-
ordinarie levie of 3000 foote, and 300 horse, to
be imploied in
e fielde for 7 monethes,
e same
is urged continually by
e
Councel of state
: and
besides they are in hand w
t
a newe remonstrance
for
e reducing of every cornet of horse, in their
pay, whiche are commonly nowe of 70 horse, to
the nomber of 120. They have also determi-
ned to crave her Ma
ties
assistance, for
e like aug-
mentation to be made in
e Englishe horsebandes:
for effecting wherof both
e Councell and
Count
Maurice
have intreated me earnestly, to hold
a good hand in their behalf and to accompanie
their sute, w
t
my privat letters to her Ma
tie
.
They alleage unto me for it, that her Hig
nes
for-
wardnes therein will move
e Provinces
e sooner,
to passe their assents: and thoughe
e surcharge
in 4 cornets, for 7 monethes, will mount to
very litle for her Ma
ties
portion, yet in computa-
tion of
e whole, the renforcement will arise
to a rownde increase. W
t
all they are in hope,
that although their Proposition to
e states, doth
specifie but 7 monethes, yet when their pur-
pose is obtened, they shall be able by persua-
sion, to continue them still in
e self same state.
For answear wherunto I lette
them understand, howe excessively, and w
t
out
intermission her Hig
nes
is charged, w
t
e warres
of these contreis, w
t
relieving
e
Frenche Kinge
,
w
t
disboursing of her treasure for
e Germaine
Levies, w
t
furnishing her shippes to annoye the
fol.48v
Enemie by sea, and sundrie other waies, for w
ch
I
could not be persuaded, that she would willingly
enter into a further charge, especially heere, where
her Ma
tie
they see, doth continually protest against
their ingratitude. Nevertheles being one of
their assembly, I would not refuse, to joine my
letters w
t
theirs, and to be as earnest in their cause,
as conveniently I might, my duty respected.
And as I am often bold, upon my
wonted confidence in yo
r
honorable liking, to say
my opinion to many thinges, so I thinke it not
impertinent to signifie in this, that though her
Ma
tie
be not willing, as I presume she is not, to
hearken to their motion, yet it will be very re-
quisit, to intertene
e Councel for a time, in
some litle kinde of hope of obtening
of
their sute.
For they will use it as a meanes, to drawe the
generallitie to a greater contribution, for the for-
said levies: and besides, as I writte in my
former, two daies past, if her Hig
nes
be resol-
ved to send some part of her forces to
e aide
of
e Kinge, when
e contrey is provided of
these newe supplies, the w
t
drawing of her subjects
will be lesse offensive to this people, and not so
hurtfull to their cause, as it is greatly to be
feared it might otherwise prove. But
yo
r
L. knowing their demaunde will easely
conceave w
at
answear is fittest w
ch
I referre
accordingly to yo
r
L. wisedome,
and take
my humble leave. From
e Hage. Ja
n
16. 90.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden. Tho. Bodley
